b'Unless the producer is ill (from things like heavy metals or contagious pathogens), human milk produced by any human is safe for infants to drink. The larger concern is usually the quantity produced, as an insufficient production of breast milk requires supplemental feeding.'

b'However, breast enlargement and milk production can occur at many different ages and outside of pregnancy as well. It is less common, and sometimes occurs because of medical disorders, but small amounts of lactation are normal quirks of breast tissue in all groups of humans.'

b'The main factors contributing to milk production are breast tissue development and hormone quantities in the body, particularly progesterone, prolactin, and oxytocin. In humans (though not all mammals), development of male and female breast tissue is very similar.'
